articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents:
Education
2016 | Ph.D. in BiostatisticsUniversity of Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
2013 | Master’s degree “Biostatistics, Bioinformatics, Biomathematics and Health”University of Lyon 1, Lyon, France
2013 | Engineering degreeEcole Centrale Marseille, Marseille, France
Professional experiences
2022 | Associate Professor in Biostatistics
University of Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
2019 - 2022 | Postdoctorate researcherBordeaux Population Health, Inserm U1219, University of Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
2017 - 2019 | Research associateInstitute of Public Health, Cambridge University, Cambridge, the United Kingdom
2014 - 2016 | Teaching assistantISPED, University of Bordeaux, Bordeaux, France
Prizes and distinctions
2023 | Publication of the Year Award, Professional Interest Areas, Design and Data Analytics, ISTAART, Alzheimer’s Association.
2017 | Young Biometrician Award, British and Irish Region of the International Biometric Society and Fisher Memorial Trust.
2015 | Student Award, International Biometric Society Channel Conference - Nijmegen, the Netherlands.
Software
CInLPN | Estimation of causal dynamic models for multiple repeated markers (categorical and continuous) and competing events [link]
PReMiuMlongi | Nonparametric Bayesian estimation of mixture models for continuous repeated outcome and correlated covariates [link]
lcmm | Estimation of joint latent class models for semi-competing risks with interval censoring [link]

articles.title: Anaïs Rouanet
articles.contents:
Anaïs Rouanet
          
          
          Home
          Publications
          CV
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Anaïs Rouanet

                        Email
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            I am a tenured assistant professor at the Bordeaux School
            of Public Health (ISPED), University of Bordeaux,
            France. My main areas of research focus on the development
            of biostatistical methods for the study of brain aging, in
            particular semi-supervised clustering and joint modelling
            approaches for multivariate longitudinal data and
            time-to-event data.
            In 2017-2019, I worked at the Institute of Public Health,
            Medical Research Council, Cambridge University, in the
            Biostatistics Unit, on the development of nonparametric
            Bayesian methods for clustering from longitudinal data and
            correlated covariates.
            In 2016, I was awarded my Ph.D. in Public Health,
            Biostatistics, from the Bordeaux University (“Study of
            dementia and cognitive decline accounting for selection by
            death”).

              I am a tenured assistant professor at the Bordeaux
              School of Public Health (ISPED), University of
              Bordeaux, France. My main areas of research focus on the
              development of biostatistical methods for the study of
              brain aging, in particular semi-supervised clustering and
              joint modelling approaches for multivariate longitudinal
              data and time-to-event data.
              In 2017-2019, I worked at the Institute of Public
              Health, Medical Research Council, Cambridge University, in
              the Biostatistics Unit, on the development of
              nonparametric Bayesian methods for clustering from
              longitudinal data and correlated covariates.
              In 2016, I was awarded my Ph.D. in Public Health,
              Biostatistics, from the Bordeaux University (“Study of
              dementia and cognitive decline accounting for selection by
              death”).

articles.title: Publications
articles.contents:
Publiés
Approaches to timescale choice in cognitive aging research and potential implications for estimated exposure effects: coordinated analyses in ten cohorts of older adults. E Hayes-Larson, RM Andrews, KL Kezios, A Bercu, A Rouanet, …, & ER Mayeda. Epidemiology, 2025, DOI: 10.1097/EDE.0000000000001859 [link]
Bayesian profile regression for clustering analysis involving a longitudinal response and explanatory variables. A Rouanet, R Johnson, M Strauss, S Richardson, B Tom, S White, P Kirk. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series C: Applied Statistics, 2023, 73 (2), 314-339, [link]
How Selection Over Time Contributes to the Inconsistency of the Association between Sex/Gender and Cognitive Decline across Cognitive Aging Cohorts. A Rouanet, J Avila-Rieger, A Dugravot, …, & C Proust-Lima. American Journal of Epidemiology, 2022, 191(3):441-452. [link]
Investigating the association between cancer and the risk of dementia: Results from the Memento cohort. JD Chamberlain, A Rouanet, …, & C Dufouil, Memento Study group. Alzheimer’s & Dementia, 2021, 17(9):1415-1421. [link]
The Alzheimer’s disease prediction of longitudinal evolution (TADPOLE) challenge: Results after 1 year follow-up. RV Marinescu, …, A Rouanet, …, & DC Alexander. Machine Learning for Biomedical Imaging, 2021, 1:1-60. [link]
Benefit of Bayesian clustering of longitudinal data: study of cognitive decline for precision medicine. A Rouanet, S Richardson, B Tom. In Bayesian Methods in Pharmaceutical Research, (eds: Lesaffre E, Baio G, and Boulanger B), Chapman & Hall/CRC Biostatistics Series, 2020, 223-242, eBook ISBN9781315180212.
[link]
Quantile regression for incomplete longitudinal data with selection by death. H Jacqmin-Gadda, A Rouanet, RD Mba, V Philipps, J-F Dartigues. Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 2020, 29(9):2697-2716. [link]
Interpretation of mixed models and marginal models with cohort attrition due to death and drop-out. A Rouanet, C Helmer, J-F Dartigues, H Jacqmin-Gadda. Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 2017, 28(2):343-356. [link]
Joint latent class model for longitudinal data and interval-censored semi-competing events: Application to dementia. A Rouanet, P Joly, J-F Dartigues, C Proust-Lima, H Jacqmin-Gadda. Biometrics, 2016, 72(4):1123-1135. [link]
Validity of shape as a predictive biomarker of final infarct volume in acute ischemic stroke. C Frindel, A Rouanet, …, & D Rousseau. Stroke, 2015, 46(4):976-981. [link]
